Comment: Its already hitting in various ways. I do ad sales on the internet using the super-massive social media systems. Lots of ads, but it tells you exactly where the economy is. The people I work with are middle class American buyers for items that are $500-1500.   At least as far as that market goes, this is the worst month for rates in the past 3 years. Jan/Feb were better than expected, but in April, it started taking a pretty notable downturn. It will be interesting where things will be in 3-4 months when the parts that the things I market towards have their prices increase since a fair bit of the "Made in America" stuff still uses Chinese/overseas components. That is where I expect things to potentially get worse. We will see though.

Author: blandunoffensivename

Comment: Not tools, mostly fittings. The LFMC and LFNC fittings from T&B and ABB Adaptaflex, mostly made in the UK, are far and away better than that Hubbell/RACO junk we we get here in the US. They fit better and seal better, and have real neoprene gaskets instead of a piece of yellow nylon. ANAMET out of Illinois is an exception but they are harder to find at distributors.  NEMA enclosures are another example. Compare the paint quality on a RITTAL to a brand new NEMA 3R or NEMA 4 Hoffman and you‚Äôll immediately see the difference. I‚Äôve got a brand new Hoffman out of the shrink wrap and I can see the paint is already flaking off in a couple places near the lid edges. Now I realize we do a lot of things for cost when it doesn‚Äôt matter much otherwise, but when paint flakes off and the shitty galvanized coating wears down you get nucleation spots for corrosion. Note that everyone else in the world uses nickel-plated brass fittings, but zinc-plated steel is basically all we use here unless we import them from another country for a critical application. Stainless steel is the exception but that‚Äôs mainly for food processing since it‚Äôs incredibly expensive and susceptible to galling.

Comment: I‚Äôm not an electrician but I‚Äôm a failure analysis engineer. So when there‚Äôs a gas line explosion or something I work to reconstruct what happened with micro CT scans and metallurgical analysis, things like that. Yes it‚Äôs mostly high-end industrial installations and for most people paint quality doesn‚Äôt functionally matter, but when it does we just don‚Äôt have the manufacturing expertise in the US that we used to. Look at any control cabinet for an important process and you‚Äôll see a lot of German and UK made stuff.
